user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     * Note there is a possibility that another thread is concurrently taking this sem,
     * and has just checked the current_value but not yet inside the cond_wait call.
     *
     * To address this possibility - the lock must be taken here.  This is unfortunate
     * as it means there may be a task switch when _giving_ a binary semaphore.  But the
     * alternative of having a BinSemGive not wake up the other thread is a bigger issue.
     *
     * Counting sems do not suffer from this, as there is a native POSIX mechanism for those.
     *
     * Note: This lock should be readily available, with only minimal delay if any.
     * If a long delay occurs here, it means something is fundamentally wrong.
     */

    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* Binary semaphores are always set as "1" when given */
    sem->current_value = 1;

    /* unblock one thread that is waiting on this sem */
    pthread_cond_signal(&(sem->cv));

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&(sem->id));

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_MAX_BIN_SEMAPHORES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t       id;
    pthread_cond_t        cv;
    volatile sig_atomic_t flush_request;
    volatile sig_atomic_t current_value;
} OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found. All pointer usages in the provided code are either already const-qualified where appropriate or must remain non-const because the pointed-to objects are modified: 
- The function parameter is declared const (const OS_object_token_t *token). 
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken already accepts a const OS_object_token_t * and is used via the macro. 
- The local sem pointer refers to an element of OS_impl_bin_sem_table that is modified (sem->current_value, pthread_cond_signal on sem->cv, mutex operations on sem->id), so it must be a pointer to a non-const record. 
- OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex takes a pthread_mutex_t * which is used to lock/unlock the mutex and therefore cannot point to const. 
- pthread_cond_signal and pthread_mutex_unlock require non-const pointers to their objects. 
- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro merely forms an address-of a table element and passes the token address to a function expecting a const pointer; there is no loss of const qualification at any call site shown. 
Given these facts, there are no locations in the supplied code where a pointer could reasonably be changed to point to a const-qualified type without preventing required modifications.
